content.text: (i) Complete the frequency column in the table.
(ii) Work out the percentage of people who cycle that are students.
1 (a) One day, Mahika records the number of teachers and students who cycle to school.

content.text: (i) Complete the table.
(ii) One of the 120 students is chosen at random.
Work out the probability that this student does not travel by bus to school.
(b) Mahika records how 120 students from Year 1 and Year 2 travel to school.
Each student walks, cycles or travels by bus.
- 48 students are in Year 1.
- 77 students walk.
- 5 students in Year 2 cycle.
- 36 students travel by bus.
- \(\frac{4}{9}\) of the students who travel by bus are in Year 1 .
(i) Complete the table.
(ii) Complete the pie chart.
(c) There have been 24 complaints about one of the buses.
The complaints are:
- The bus is late.
- The price is too high.
- The bus is crowded.
2 (a) Calculate the interior angle of a regular pentagon.
(i) Work out the value of \(x\).
Give a geometrical reason for your answer.
(ii) Work out the value of \(y\). Give a geometrical reason for your answer.
(iii) Find the ratio \(x: y\). Give your answer in its simplest form.
(b) The diagram shows three congruent regular pentagons and a triangle.
3 (a) The diagram shows three quadrilaterals, \(A, B\) and \(C\), on a \(1 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\) grid.
(i) (a) Write down the mathematical name for quadrilateral \(B\). (b) Work out the area of quadrilateral \(B\). Give the units of your answer.
(b) The diagram shows a parallelogram and a line \(A B\) on a \(1 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\) grid.
On the grid, complete a triangle, \(A B C\), that has the same area as the parallelogram.
(i) Write down the mathematical name of the line
\(X, Y\) and \(Z\) lie on a circle, centre \(O\).
(i) Use the information in the diagram to complete these two simultaneous equations.
(c) In this part, all angles are in degrees.
\(A, B, C\) and \(D\) lie on a circle, centre \(O\), diameter \(A C\).
\(X Y\) is a tangent to the circle at \(D\).
(i) Draw a net of the box on the \(1 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\) grid.
(ii) A container is a cube with volume \(1 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\).
Work out the maximum number of these boxes that can be packed into this container.
5 (a) A closed box, in the shape of a cuboid, has length 5 cm , width 4 cm and height 2 cm .
(i) Work out the cost in rupees of box \(B\).

Calculate the mass of box \(C\).

Give your answer in kilograms.
(b) A shop sells three different sized boxes of rice.
The boxes all have the same cost per kilogram.
(i) Work out the cost in rupees of box \(B\).
(c) Change \(75 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) into litres.
(ii) A container is a cube with volume \(1 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\).
(c) Change \(75 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) into litres.
(b) A shop sells three different sized boxes of rice.
The boxes all have the same cost per kilogram.
(i) The spinner is spun once.
Write down the probability that the spinner lands on
The diagram shows a fair 9-sided spinner.
The numbers on the spinner are 2, 3, 5, 5, 5, 6, 6, 7 and 8 .
(i) Write down the mode.
(ii) Work out the range.
(iii) Work out the median.
(iv) Calculate the mean.
(b) a number less than 7 .
7 (a) 1 mile \(=1.609344\) kilometres
Change 6 miles into metres.
Give your answer correct to the nearest metre.
(b) (i) The bearing of a boat from a harbour is \(322^{\circ}\).
Work out the bearing of the harbour from the boat.
(ii) The boat is 12 km from the harbour. At 2.30 pm the boat starts to sail to the harbour. The speed of the boat is 5 km/h .
Work out the time the boat arrives at the harbour.
(i) Measure the bearing of \(M\) from \(S\).
(ii)
Scale: 1 cm to 5 km
This scale drawing shows another map with Shakti's house, \(S\), marked on it.
The scale of this map is 1 cm represents 5 km .
Mark the position of Mairi's house, \(M\), on this map.
(c) The scale drawing shows the positions of Shakti's house, \(S\), and Mairi's house, \(M\), on a map. The scale is 1 cm represents 4 km .
8 (a) (i) Complete the table of values for \(y=x^{2}+6 x-160\).
(ii) On the grid, draw the graph of \(y=x^{2}+6 x-160\) for \(-20 \leqslant x \leqslant 15\).
(b) Find the coordinates of the lowest point on the graph.
(i) Show that angle \(P R Q=90^{\circ}\).
(ii) Calculate the area of the quadrilateral \(P Q R S\).
Give your answer correct to 4 significant figures.
The diagram shows Tarak's two triangular fields, \(P Q R\) and \(P R S\).
Angle \(R P S=90^{\circ}\) and angle \(P R S=53^{\circ}\).
\(P Q=174 \mathrm{~m}, Q R=120 \mathrm{~m}\) and \(P R=126 \mathrm{~m}\).
(b) (i) The mass, \(m\) tonnes, of wheat grown in 2021 is 4.3 tonnes, correct to 1 decimal place.
Complete this statement about the value of \(m\).

\(
\leqslant m <
\)
(ii) In 2020, 2.6 tonnes of barley is grown. In 2021, 3.25 tonnes of barley is grown.
Show that the percentage increase in barley grown from 2020 to 2021 is \(25 \%\).
(iii) In 2019, 2.4 tonnes of corn is grown. In 2020, \(20 \%\) more corn is grown than in 2019. In 2021, \(20 \%\) less corn is grown than in 2020.
Calculate the amount of corn grown in 2021.
9 Tarak has two fields.
He grows wheat, barley and corn in his fields.
